triples.name: Species diversity
triples.relevance: The paper addresses how diverse ecosystems maintain stability, building on foundational concepts of species diversity.

triples.name: Ecological stability
triples.relevance: The paper explains mechanisms underlying ecosystem stability across different diversity levels.

triples.name: Power law
triples.relevance: The paper proposes that growth scales as a sublinear power law, a novel contribution to understanding ecosystem dynamics.

triples.name: Density dependence
triples.relevance: The sublinear growth model exhibits density-dependent self-regulation, a novel mechanism proposed in this paper.

triples.name: Competition (biology)
triples.relevance: The paper analyzes how competitive interactions among populations change with different growth models.

triples.name: Logistic function
triples.relevance: The paper contrasts its sublinear growth model with logistic growth, the standard population ecology model.

triples.name: Competitive exclusion principle
triples.relevance: The paper addresses how sublinear growth prevents competitive exclusion, contrasting with this classical ecological principle.

triples.name: Biodiversity loss
triples.relevance: The paper addresses the worldwide loss of species diversity as the motivation for understanding ecosystem stability.

triples.name: Macroecology
triples.relevance: The paper predicts large-scale macroecological patterns emerging from its theoretical model.
